The tenement is shows strong outcrop, dominantly ultramafic material, with layers of 
 basaltic rock. Historical exploration has focused on gold, with some exploration in the 
 1970s for nickel. Best available historical results indicate a maximum gold in drilling of 
 A soil programme is being planned to cover this and nearby Heron held tenements.

29.text: P15/4678 lies within the Coolgardie Domain (Swagger 1997) one of five well defined

30.text: western domains forming the Kalgoorlie Terrane and is bounded by the Zuleika and

31.text: Bullabuling Shears.  The Coolgardie Domain stratigraphy is characterised on the basis

32.text: of a thin or absent upper basalt layer and structural repetition of the komatiite layer

text:
felsic volcanics. The upper basalt is thought to represent a fractional crystallisation from 
 the komatiite layer, and thus have a different origin to the lower basalt. In contrast to the 
 surrounding terranes the Kalgoorlie Terrane greenstones do not appear to contain BIF. 
 P15/4678 lies within the Coolgardie Domain (Swagger 1997) one of five well defined 
 western domains forming the Kalgoorlie Terrane and is bounded by the Zuleika and 
 Bullabuling Shears.  The Coolgardie Domain stratigraphy is characterised on the basis 
 of a thin or absent upper basalt layer and structural repetition of the komatiite layer 
 2.2 Prospect Geology 
 P15/4678 is a small strip to the west of the old Gibraltar Mine. This places it over 
 interlayered ultramafic and mafic rocks, and comparatively strong outcrop.

 A number of other tenements in the same area are currently not available as open file 
 data and are being requested. One of the open-file regional geochemistry datasets 
 obtained by Heron contains a number of data points in this tenement (Figure 5.) with 
 results of up to 112 ppm gold.

14.text: Golden  Mile  deposit.  Most  average  around  2  t  of  gold.  With  improving  technology

15.text: and gold price the economic grade of these materials has fallen from around 40 g/t

16.text: in the 1890s to around 5 g/t. Most currently active have grades in the range of 4 – 9

17.text: g/t, although this may reduce in areas of strongly weathered regolith.

19.text: Lode-gold  deposits  may  form  in  any  lithology  within  a  greenstone  belt,  however

text:
Golden  Mile  deposit.  Most  average  around  2  t  of  gold.  With  improving  technology 
 and gold price the economic grade of these materials has fallen from around 40 g/t 
 in the 1890s to around 5 g/t. Most currently active have grades in the range of 4 – 9 
 g/t, although this may reduce in areas of strongly weathered regolith. 
 Lode-gold  deposits  may  form  in  any  lithology  within  a  greenstone  belt,  however

20.text: spatial  analysis  suggests  preferences  (Groves  1990).  Rheological  factors  are

21.text: important,  as  a  brittle  material  is  more  likely  to  localise  fluid  flow  and  thus  allow

22.text: mineralization. Chemical composition also plays a role, with Fe or Fe-+Mg rich rocks

23.text: capable of destabilizing gold complexes precipitating Fe sulphides and gold. This is

24.text: the  situation  in  the  Kalgoorlie  and  Kambalda  districts  where  major  gold-lode

25.text: deposits are hosted within mafic rocks. Within the Pilbara Craton examples exist of

28.text: There  is  a  gross  relationship  between  the  location  of  Archaean  lode-gold  deposits

29.text: and crustal-scale deformation zones in the Yilgarn Craton. A similar relationship has

30.text: been  noted  in  Canada  (Robert  1990).  Despite  this  large-scale  relationship,  gold

31.text: mineralisation  is  rarely  hosted  in  first-order  structures,  and  deposits  are  instead

32.text: hosted  in  second  and  lower  order  structures,  which  may  or  may  not  show  a  direct

33.text: geometric  relationship  to  the  large-scale  deformation  zones  (e.g.  Eisenlohr  et  al.

34.text: 1989). The general lack of mineralisation within the major structures suggest that, if

35.text: the  structures  are  interlinked  and  the  major  structures  acted  as  fluid  conduits,  they

36.text: did so at deeper crustal levels than those currently exposed in most gold deposits.

38.text: The  structural  styles  of  individual  gold  deposits  broadly  reflect  the  metamorphic

39.text: conditions  under  which  they  formed.  At  low  metamorphic  grades,  brittle  tensional

40.text: quartz  veins  and  breccias  dominate  (e.g.  Wiluna).  These  give  way  to  brittle-ductile

41.text: laminated quartz veins at mid to upper greenschist-facies conditions (e.g. Kalgoorlie)

42.text: and  ductile  shear-zone-hosted  mineralisation  at  amphioblite  and  granulite-facies

43.text: conditions  (e.g.  Southern  Cross).  Gold  mineralisation  occurs  syn-  to  post-peak

46.text: movement.  Importantly,  it  is  often  associated  with  the  last  significant  movement  on

49.text: Most  Archaean  gold-lode  geochronological  data  supports  a  mineralization  range

50.text: ~2640-2630  Ma.  However,  a  number  of  studies  are  indicating  earlier  dates,  e.g.

51.text: Mount McClure on the Yandal Greenstone Belt (Yeats and McNaughton 1997).

text:
spatial  analysis  suggests  preferences  (Groves  1990).  Rheological  factors  are 
 important,  as  a  brittle  material  is  more  likely  to  localise  fluid  flow  and  thus  allow 
 mineralization. Chemical composition also plays a role, with Fe or Fe-+Mg rich rocks 
 capable of destabilizing gold complexes precipitating Fe sulphides and gold. This is 
 the  situation  in  the  Kalgoorlie  and  Kambalda  districts  where  major  gold-lode 
 deposits are hosted within mafic rocks. Within the Pilbara Craton examples exist of 
 BIF and sedimentary gold lodes. 
 There  is  a  gross  relationship  between  the  location  of  Archaean  lode-gold  deposits 
 and crustal-scale deformation zones in the Yilgarn Craton. A similar relationship has 
 been  noted  in  Canada  (Robert  1990).  Despite  this  large-scale  relationship,  gold 
 mineralisation  is  rarely  hosted  in  first-order  structures,  and  deposits  are  instead 
 hosted  in  second  and  lower  order  structures,  which  may  or  may  not  show  a  direct 
 geometric  relationship  to  the  large-scale  deformation  zones  (e.g.  Eisenlohr  et  al. 
 1989). The general lack of mineralisation within the major structures suggest that, if 
 the  structures  are  interlinked  and  the  major  structures  acted  as  fluid  conduits,  they 
 did so at deeper crustal levels than those currently exposed in most gold deposits. 
 The  structural  styles  of  individual  gold  deposits  broadly  reflect  the  metamorphic 
 conditions  under  which  they  formed.  At  low  metamorphic  grades,  brittle  tensional 
 quartz  veins  and  breccias  dominate  (e.g.  Wiluna).  These  give  way  to  brittle-ductile 
 laminated quartz veins at mid to upper greenschist-facies conditions (e.g. Kalgoorlie) 
 and  ductile  shear-zone-hosted  mineralisation  at  amphioblite  and  granulite-facies 
 conditions  (e.g.  Southern  Cross).  Gold  mineralisation  occurs  syn-  to  post-peak 
 movement.  Importantly,  it  is  often  associated  with  the  last  significant  movement  on 
 is  synchronous  with  major 
 fault  or  shear-zone 
 regional  metamorphism  and 
 Most  Archaean  gold-lode  geochronological  data  supports  a  mineralization  range 
 ~2640-2630  Ma.  However,  a  number  of  studies  are  indicating  earlier  dates,  e.g. 
 Mount McClure on the Yandal Greenstone Belt (Yeats and McNaughton 1997).

21.text: Lateral  zonation of hydrothermal alteration  is characteristically  present on the  scale

22.text: of  centimetres  to  tens  of  metres.  Alteration  varies  with  metamorphic  grade,  but

23.text: mineral  assemblages  indicative  of  carbonation,  potassium  or  sodium  alteration  and

24.text: sulphidation  are  common.  Sub-amphibolite  grade  alteration  can  be  divided  into

25.text: biotite-muscovite and chlorite-muscovite alteration series. Over tholeiitic mafic rocks

29.text: similar to high grade alteration with more biotite developed in intermediate alteration

30.text: zones.  High  grade  alteration  has  a  smaller  lateral  extent,  although  chemical

31.text: development  is  similar  to  lower  temperature  alteration.  Carbonate  alteration  is  less

32.text: dominant.  Common  alteration  patterns  are  quartz-pyrite-pyrrhotite  veins  with

33.text: diopside-calcite or fibrous tremolite rims with pyrrhotite±amphibole±chlorite haloes.

35.text: Exploration for gold-lode deposits are heavily dependant on geochemical methods,

36.text: despite gold generally being depleted in weathered cover. Geophysical responses are

37.text: generally poor. Soil, rock-chip and regolith geochemistry are the most widely used

38.text: regional exploration tools. In areas of transported cover RAB drilling may be preferred.

39.text: Gold analysed to low ppb levels is the best pathfinder mineral for these deposits,

40.text: although As, Bi, Sb, W and Mo have also been utilised in exploration.

text:
separated gold-lode deposits into: 
 1.  Silver-rich (more silver than gold) and; 
 2.  Gold rich deposits. 
 Silver-rich deposits can be further divided as gold-rich end members of VHMS, Cu-
 Ag-Au  veins  or porphyry deposits. All these  styles are  rich in sulphides, particularly 
 chalcopyrite,  which  further  separates  them  from  the  typically  copper  poor  gold-rich 
 form.  These  are  rare  in  Australian  settings,  but  include  Boddington,  Mount  Gibson 
 and Golden Grove. 
 Gold-rich  forms  may  be  separated  in  to  two  styles;  quartz-carbonate  veins  and 
 disseminated-replacement deposits. Of these two the quartz-carbonate form is more 
 common.  They  characteristically  show  enrichment  of  Ag,  As,  and  W;  variable 
 enrichment in Bi, Sb, Te and B. A low salinity, H2O-CO2 +/- CH4 fluid is important at 
 Lateral  zonation of hydrothermal alteration  is characteristically  present on the  scale 
 of  centimetres  to  tens  of  metres.  Alteration  varies  with  metamorphic  grade,  but 
 mineral  assemblages  indicative  of  carbonation,  potassium  or  sodium  alteration  and 
 sulphidation  are  common.  Sub-amphibolite  grade  alteration  can  be  divided  into 
 biotite-muscovite and chlorite-muscovite alteration series. Over tholeiitic mafic rocks 
 (ankerite±siderite-) sericite-pyrite±pyrrhotite alteration. Biotite-muscovite sequence is 
 shows  distal 
 chlorite  alteration  grading 
 to 
 chlorite-muscovite  alteration 
 similar to high grade alteration with more biotite developed in intermediate alteration 
 zones.  High  grade  alteration  has  a  smaller  lateral  extent,  although  chemical 
 development  is  similar  to  lower  temperature  alteration.  Carbonate  alteration  is  less 
 dominant.  Common  alteration  patterns  are  quartz-pyrite-pyrrhotite  veins  with 
 diopside-calcite or fibrous tremolite rims with pyrrhotite±amphibole±chlorite haloes. 
 Exploration for gold-lode deposits are heavily dependant on geochemical methods, 
 despite gold generally being depleted in weathered cover. Geophysical responses are 
 generally poor. Soil, rock-chip and regolith geochemistry are the most widely used 
 regional exploration tools. In areas of transported cover RAB drilling may be preferred. 
 Gold analysed to low ppb levels is the best pathfinder mineral for these deposits, 
 although As, Bi, Sb, W and Mo have also been utilised in exploration.

 5.3 Further Exploration 
 Further exploration will begin with a soils programme over this area. It is also necessary 
 to further investigate previous activities in this area. Subject to satisfactory results from 
 this survey reconnaissance RAB drilling may be undertaken.
